projectDesc.p: "The King of Tars" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: The King of Tars

app.lem: Herkneþ to me boþe eld & ȝing,
app.rdg: Listen to me, both old and young,

app.lem: For Maries loue þat swete þing,
app.rdg: For the love of Mary, that precious woman,
About how a war began
Between a true, Christian king
And a pagan high lord,
The sultan of Damascus.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars hadde a wiue,
app.rdg: The King of Tars had [married] a wife,
Of whom any man could say
A lovelier woman had never lived.

app.lem: A douhter þai hadde hem bitven,
app.rdg: Between them they bore a daughter,
Than whom no woman might be lovelier,

app.lem: As white as feþer of swan.
app.rdg: As white as the feather of a swan.

app.lem: Þe meiden was schast & bliþe of chere,
app.rdg: The maiden was chaste and happy in appearance,

app.lem: Wiþ rode red so blosme on brere,
app.rdg: With cheeks as red as a flower on a bush,
And [with] bright grey eyes;
With low shoulders and a white neck,

app.lem: Hir forto sen was gret preier
app.rdg: To court her was the wish
Of proud and youthful princes.

app.lem: Þe los of hir gan spring wide
app.rdg: The talk of her did spread about

app.lem: In oþer londes bi ich a side;
app.rdg: In other countries on every side;

app.lem: So þe soudan herd it say.
app.rdg: So the sultan heard it spoken.

app.lem: Him þouȝt his hert it brast o fiue
app.rdg: He thought his heart would break in five pieces

app.lem: Bot ȝif he miȝt haue hir to wiue
app.rdg: Unless he could have her as his wife,

app.lem: Þat was so feir a may.
app.rdg: [She] Who was so lovely a maiden.
He did summon all his messengers,
And ordered them all to go quickly
To her father, the king;

app.lem: & seyd he wald, houso it bifalle,
app.rdg: He said whatever it takes, he would

app.lem: His douhter cloþe in riche palle,
app.rdg: Dress his daughter in royal robes
And wed her with his ring.
If he would not, then without fail,

app.lem: He wald hir win in batayl
app.rdg: He would win her in battle
With many a high lord.
The messengers set out
To obey the sultan’s command
Without any delay.

app.lem: Þan þe king of Tars þis vnderstode,
app.rdg: Once the King of Tars learned this,

app.lem: Almest for wretþe he wex ner wode,
app.rdg: He almost nearly went mad out of anger
And by his words said this:

app.lem: ‘Bi him þat dyed on þe rode,
app.rdg: “By He who died on the cross,

app.lem: Ich wald arst spille min hert-blode
app.rdg: I would sooner shed my heart’s blood
And be killed in battle.

app.lem: Y nold hir ȝiue a Sarazin
app.rdg: I will never give her to a Muslim

app.lem: For alle þe lond þat is mine;
app.rdg: For all the land I rule,
Let the devil sooner hang him!

app.lem: Bot sche wil wiþ hir gode wille
app.rdg: Unless, with her consent, she will

app.lem: Be wedded to him hirselue to spille;
app.rdg: Be married to him and spoil herself.

app.lem: Hir þouȝtes nouȝt y no knawe,
app.rdg: I ought not to know her thoughts,

app.lem: Ac y schal wite ar þan ȝe pas.’
app.rdg: “But I shall learn them before anything happens.”

app.lem: His douhter anon was brouȝt in plas,
app.rdg: His daughter was brought before him at once,
And he asked her immediately:
“Daughter, the sultan of Damascus
Longs to see your face
And would take you as his wife.
Daughter, would you for his riches
Turn back on Jesus, our saviour,
Who suffered five wounds?”

app.lem: Þe maiden answerd wiþ mild mod
app.rdg: The maiden answered with mild manner

app.lem: Biforn hir fader þer sche stode,
app.rdg: From where she stood before her father:
“Never, lord, so let me live!
“Jesus, my Lord in trinity,

app.lem: Lat me neuer þat day yse
app.rdg: Let me never see the day
I marry a tyrant.
One [Almighty] God, [who is in] three persons,

app.lem: For Marie loue, þi moder fre,
app.rdg: For the love of Mary, Your queenly mother,
Sooner give him pain and retribution.”
The king said: “Daughter, be at ease.

app.lem: Þou schalt neuer be wedded him tille,
app.rdg: You shall never be married to him,

app.lem: For no bost he can make.
app.rdg: No matter what threats he makes.

app.lem: Y schal him sende word oȝein
app.rdg: I shall send him reply

app.lem: Þat alle his þouȝtes ben in vein,
app.rdg: That all his advances are in vain,
Because you have rejected him.”
By the same messengers

app.lem: Þat com fro þe soudan fers,
app.rdg: That came from the wicked sultan,
[The king] sent him back these words:

app.lem: Þat sche leued nouȝt on his maners;
app.rdg: That she did not believe in his principles,

app.lem: Sche nold nouȝt leten hir preiers
app.rdg: [And] She would never cease her prayers
To God omnipotent.

app.lem: He bad him tak anoþer thouȝt,
app.rdg: He suggested [to the sultan] that he reconsider,

app.lem: For of his douhter no tit him nouȝt
app.rdg: Because he was not entitled to his daughter
Neither for his riches nor for purchase.

app.lem: Þe messangers herd him þus seyn,
app.rdg: So the messengers heard him say,

app.lem: Wiþ þat word þai turned oȝain
app.rdg: [And] With that word they turned back
And returned to the sultan.

app.lem: As þe soudan sat at his des,
app.rdg: They came into the hall (87)
As the sultan sat upon his throne, (85)
Having eaten the morning meal. (86)

app.lem: Bifor þo princes prout in pres
app.rdg: Before the battle-hardened princes

app.lem: Her tale to telle wiþouten les
app.rdg: They fell down upon their knees (90)

app.lem: On knes þai gun doun falle.
app.rdg: To tell their tale, without any deceit. (89)

app.lem: Þai seyd ‘sir, þe king of Tars
app.rdg: They said: “Sire, the King of Tars

app.lem: Of wicked wordes is nouȝt scars;
app.rdg: Is not wanting of wicked words.

app.lem: Heþen hounde he gan þe calle,
app.rdg: ‘Pagan hound’ he did call you,

app.lem: & ar he ȝiue his douhter þe t[i]lle
app.rdg: And [said that] before he his gives his daughter up to you
He will shed your heart’s blood,
And [the blood] of all your barons.”

app.lem: When þe soudan þis wordes herd,
app.rdg: When the sultan heard these words,

app.lem: Also a wilde bore he ferd;
app.rdg: He acted like a wild boar.
He tore apart his robes,

app.lem: His here he rent of heued & berd.
app.rdg: [And] He pulled the hair from his head and beard.

app.lem: He schuld venge him wiþ his swerd,
app.rdg: He swore on the saint [prophet] Muhammad (102)
That he should avenge himself with his sword. (101)

app.lem: Þe table so heteliche he smot
app.rdg: He struck the table so hatefully

app.lem: It fel into þe flore fot-hot,
app.rdg: That it crashed down to the floor,
And [he] looked like a lion.

app.lem: Al þat he rauȝt he smot doun riȝt:
app.rdg: Everything that he touched, he struck down:
Sergeant, squire, clerk, and knight,
Both earl and baron.

app.lem: Al þus þe soudan ferd, y pliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed, the sultan acted thusly

app.lem: Al þat day & alle þat niȝt;
app.rdg: All the day and all the night;
Not a man could handle him.
In the morning, when it was light,

app.lem: His messangers he sent ful riȝt
app.rdg: Right away he sent his messengers
Posthaste to his barons

app.lem: Þat þai com to his parlement
app.rdg: So that they meet in his war-room
To hear his plan,
From both the least to the greatest.
When the council of war was assembled
The mighty sultan spoke,
And said to them in haste:
“Lords,” he said, “give me your advice.

app.lem: Me haþ ben don a gret misdede
app.rdg: I have been terribly insulted
By the Christian King of Tars!

app.lem: Y bede him boþe lond & lede
app.rdg: I offered to him both [my] land and [my] subjects

app.lem: For his douhter, worþliche in wede,
app.rdg: For his daughter, desirable in marriage,

app.lem: To han wed hir wiþ ring.
app.rdg: To have married her with my ring.
He has sent me reply

app.lem: In bateyl y schuld arst be sleyn
app.rdg: That I should sooner be slain in battle
And [with] many a high lord.
Indeed, he shall be destroyed -
Rather he was born into misfortune -
Than to [the destruction] I will bring.

app.lem: & þerfore ich haue after ȝou sent,
app.rdg: “That is why I have sent for you
And here assembled this council of war,
To seek your advice.”

app.lem: & alle þai seyd wiþ gode entent
app.rdg: They all said, in good faith,
[That] they awaited his command,
Surely, and without fail:

app.lem: Riȝt bi þat day a fourtenniȝt
app.rdg: Within fourteen days of that meeting

app.lem: Þai schul ben alle redi diȝt
app.rdg: They should all be made ready
With helms [and] coats of mail.

app.lem: & whan þai were so at his hest,
app.rdg: When they were thus at his command,

app.lem: Þe soudan made a riche fest
app.rdg: The sultan prepared a sumptuous feast
To celebrate the campaign.

app.lem: Þe soudan gaderd a rout vnride
app.rdg: The sultan mustered up a massive force
Of Muslims great in pride
To sally against the king.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars herd sey þat tide,
app.rdg: The King of Tars heard rumors of war;

app.lem: He gadred his ost bi ich a side,
app.rdg: He massed his army on every side,
All whom he could summon.
Then they began to grow angry,

app.lem: For þat mariage miȝt nouȝt take
app.rdg: So that marriage might not take [away]
That gentle maiden.

app.lem: Of bateyl þai gun sett a day,
app.rdg: They did prepare a day for the battle,

app.lem: Of seynt Eline, þe þridde in May.
app.rdg: [The day] of Saint Helen, the third of May.

app.lem: No lenger no wald þai lende.
app.rdg: They would permit no delay.

app.lem: Þe soudan com wiþ his pouwer,
app.rdg: The sultan came with his forces
To fight upon the field, (172)
With sixty-thousand fearsome Muslims (173)
[Bearing] bright armor and lofty banners, (171)

app.lem: Þat alle þe feldes fer & ner
app.rdg: So that all the fields near and far
Gleamed with the light from their helms.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars com wiþ his ost,
app.rdg: The King of Tars came with his army,
With great pride and haughty boast,
[And] with many a manly knight.
Either army did close with the other;

app.lem: Þer miȝt men se a strong bateyle
app.rdg: There men might see a battle
Which was gruesome to look upon.
There the [pagan] hounds cut down [with their swords] Christian men

app.lem: & feld hem doun bi niȝen & ten.
app.rdg: And cut them down [thinned their ranks] by nines and tens.
So frenzied and angry were they

app.lem: Þat men miȝt sen alle þe fen
app.rdg: That men might see [lying] upon the ground
Christian men both stranger and family;
The valleys ran wet with [their] blood.

app.lem: Þe soudan & his folk þat stounde
app.rdg: That moment, the sultan and his men
Cut down [repulsed] with gruesome wounds
Many a valiant assault.
Alas! Muhammad sped to victory.
The Christian men suffered such a defeat,
[That] there was no one who withstood [the enemy].

app.lem: Þe king of Tars seye þat siȝt,
app.rdg: The King of Tars saw the sight;

app.lem: For wretþe he was neye wode, apliȝt.
app.rdg: Indeed, he had nearly gone mad with anger.

app.lem: He hent in hond a spere,
app.rdg: He hefted a spear in his hand,

app.lem: & to þe soudan he rode ful riȝt,
app.rdg: And he rode hard upon the sultan.

app.lem: Wiþ a stroke o[f] michel miȝt
app.rdg: He took him to the ground (186)

app.lem: To grounde he gan him bere.
app.rdg: With a stroke of mighty power (185).

app.lem: Þer he hadde þe soudan slawe,
app.rdg: There he would have killed the sultan,

app.lem: Ac ten þousend of heþen lawe
app.rdg: But ten-thousand of the pagan faith
Saved him from that danger.

app.lem: Þai sett him on a ful gode stede
app.rdg: They set him on a freshened horse

app.lem: Þat was so gode at eueri nede
app.rdg: Which was so responsive to every command
hat no man could contest him.

app.lem: & when he was opon his stede,
app.rdg: When [the sultan] sat upon his horse,

app.lem: Him þouȝt he brend so spark on glede
app.rdg: They imagined he burned like an ember on a coal
Out of anger and of spite.

app.lem: He fauȝt so he wald wede;
app.rdg: He fought as if he was mad;

app.lem: Alle þat he hit he maked blede.
app.rdg: All that he struck, he made it bleed.
“Help, Muhammad!” he did shout.
There were many helms struck off,
Many visors [were] sliced in half,
And saddles [were] fallen empty.
Many swords and many shields

app.lem: & mani kniȝt lay in þe feld
app.rdg: And many knights lay [dead] on the field
Among the Christian army.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars seye him so ride;
app.rdg: The King of Tars saw him riding thusly;
He fled, and dared not linger,
Back home to his city.

app.lem: Þe Sarraȝins folwed in þat tide,
app.rdg: The Muslims followed in that instance

app.lem: & slouȝ adoun bi ich a side
app.rdg: And struck down on every side
The noble, Christian people.
There were slain thirty-thousand
Knights of the Christian faith,
And such a shame it was!
In the morning, for both of their benefit,

app.lem: Trewes þai gun bitven hem take,
app.rdg: They did make a truce between them,
For one month and three days [in duration].

app.lem: On a day þe king sat in his halle,
app.rdg: One day, the king sat in his hall
And became utterly lost in sorrow,
For his people were hopeless.

app.lem: His douhter com clad in palle,
app.rdg: His daughter came wearing robes,

app.lem: Adoun on knes sche gan to falle,
app.rdg: And she did fall on her knees,
And said with deep sighing:

app.lem: ‘Sir, lete me be þe soudans wiif,
app.rdg: “Sire, let me be the sultan’s wife,
And cause neither calamity nor strife
As there has been here since.

app.lem: For me haþ mani man ben schent,
app.rdg: Many a man has been slain for me;
Cities [have been] captured and towns [have been] burnt.
Alas, that I was ever born!

app.lem: Fader, y wil serue at wille
app.rdg: “Father, I will willingly serve
The sultan, both loud and soft [no matter the conditions],
And trust in the almighty God.

app.lem: Bot it so be, he schal þe spille,
app.rdg: Or else, he shall kill you,

app.lem: & alle þi lond take him tille,
app.rdg: And take all of your land for himself,
In battle and with war.

app.lem: Certes y nil no lenger dreye
app.rdg: Surely I will no longer bear

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk for me dye;
app.rdg: A Christian people to die for me;
It is so sorrowful a sight.”

app.lem: Þe king of Tars answerd þo,
app.rdg: Then the King of Tars answered,

app.lem: As man þat was in sorwe & wo,
app.rdg: A man who was in sorrow and woe,
To that lovely lady:
“Now, daughter, may you be blessed
By Jesus Christ in trinity

app.lem: Þe time þat þou were bore;
app.rdg: From the hour that you were born.

app.lem: For þou wilt saue þi moder & me
app.rdg: Because you will save your mother and me,

app.lem: Al þi preier graunt y þe
app.rdg: I [will] allow everything for which you have asked,
Just as you have said before.”
“Father,” she said, “without delay,
For the love of Jesus, heaven’s king,
If it were your will,

app.lem: Do now swiþe þat y war þere
app.rdg: Act now, that I will be there
Before any more sorrow arises,
So that you will not be hopeless.”

app.lem: Þe king of Tars, wiþ gode entent,
app.rdg: The King of Tars, with good intent,

app.lem: Hastilich after his wiif he sent,
app.rdg: Called for his wife immediately,

app.lem: Þat leuedi þat was so hende.
app.rdg: The lady who was so gentle.

app.lem: When sche was comen in present
app.rdg: When she had arrived in [his] presence

app.lem: He seyd ‘dame, our douhter haþ ment
app.rdg: He said: “Dame, our daughter has decided
To go over to the sultan.

app.lem: Do loke what rede is now at þe,
app.rdg: See if there is any advice you have [to give],

app.lem: For now er here bot we þre,
app.rdg: Since there are only us three
To save the Christian people.”
The queen answered without mistake:
“No, I shall never suggest that
Our daughter be put to shame.”

app.lem: Þe maiden was ful of sorwe & wo.
app.rdg: The maiden was full of sorrow and woe.
“Have mercy,” she cried to her mother then
With such a pitiful voice.
“Mother, it was not long ago

app.lem: For me were slawe kniȝtes þro,
app.rdg: That valiant knights were slain for me,
Thirty-thousand and seven [of them].

app.lem: Forþi y wil suffre no lenger þrawe
app.rdg: Therefore, I will no longer endure

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk be for me slawe,
app.rdg: Christian men to be slain for me,

app.lem: Wiþ þe grace of God in heuen.’
app.rdg: By the grace of God in heaven.”

app.lem: Þus þe maiden wiþ wordes stille
app.rdg: Thus, with gentle words the maiden

app.lem: Brouȝt hem boþe in better wille
app.rdg: Led them both to better understanding
By her honest and impartial judgment.

app.lem: & when þai were þus at on,
app.rdg: When they were in unison,
They at once sent messengers
To the wealthy sultan.

app.lem: To make his frende þat were his fon,
app.rdg: To make [themselves] his friends that were his enemies,

app.lem: & for he schuld his men nouȝt slon
app.rdg: And so [that] he should not slay his men,

app.lem: His douhter he graunt him þan.
app.rdg: [The king] then gave to him his daughter.

app.lem: Þe messangers nold no leng abide;
app.rdg: The messengers would no longer wait;

app.lem: To þe soudan þai went þat tide,
app.rdg: They went to the sultan that moment,
And thus they did tell him.
Then when the letters were read

app.lem: Þe soudan was boþe bliþe & glad,
app.rdg: The sultan was both happy and glad,
And so were many men.

app.lem: So glad he was in al maners
app.rdg: He was so pleased in every way that

app.lem: He cleped to him of his pers,
app.rdg: He summoned from his councilors to himself
Dukes, princes, and kings.

app.lem: Into a chaumber þai went yfers
app.rdg: Together they went into a store-room
To make ready for the messengers
Precious gems and expensive rings.

app.lem: Bi conseyl of þe lordinges alle
app.rdg: By the council of all his lords,

app.lem: Þe soudan dede bring into þe halle
app.rdg: The sultan did bring into the hall
Gifts and lavish trinkets,
And gave a great abundance to them,

app.lem: To þe messangers wiþ hert fre,
app.rdg: To the messengers, out of his noble heart,
And thanked them for their news.

app.lem: & seyd he was alle at his wille,
app.rdg: He said he was in full agreement,
Whether early or late [no matter the time], loud or soft,

app.lem: To help him at his nede;
app.rdg: To help [the king] with his request;

app.lem: No more folk nold he spille.
app.rdg: He would not kill any more people.

app.lem: Þe messangers went þe king tille
app.rdg: The messengers went to the king
And told him of that deed [the sultan’s response].
The king and also the queen
Were both of them happy and sad,
In the verses which we read.

app.lem: Gret ioie þai hadde, wiþouten les,
app.rdg: They were greatly relieved, without deceit,

app.lem: For þat þe soudan wald haue pes
app.rdg: Because the sultan would have peace
With Christian fellowship.

app.lem: Þe first day of Iulii tide,
app.rdg: On the first day of July,

app.lem: Þe soudan nold no leng abide,
app.rdg: The sultan would no longer wait.

app.lem: To þe king of Tars he sent
app.rdg: He sent to the King of Tars
Many knights of great strength

app.lem: & riche iewels, is nouȝt to hide,
app.rdg: And jewels too precious to keep hidden away,
To give [to the King] as his bride-price.
The messengers, without delay,

app.lem: Com to Tars, bifor þe king,
app.rdg: Came before the King of Tars
To receive his gentle daughter.

app.lem: Þai welcomed hem wiþ glad chere.
app.rdg: They welcomed him with a happy appearance.

app.lem: Of gret pite, now may ȝe here,
app.rdg: [They appeared] deeply grieved, now you may hear,
When they went into the bedroom.
They wept and grieved sorely

app.lem: For þai schuld her douhter forgo
app.rdg: Because they should give up their daughter
And send her to the sultan.

app.lem: Þe maiden preyd hem boþe þo
app.rdg: Then the maiden begged both of them

app.lem: Þat þai schuld bi her conseyl do
app.rdg: That they should act on her advice
To save the Christian people:

app.lem: ‘For y wil suffre no lenger þrawe
app.rdg: “For I will no longer endure

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk be for me slawe.’
app.rdg: Christian people to be slain for me.”
They did return to the hall
And welcomed those messengers

app.lem: Þat com from þe soudan fers
app.rdg: That came from the wicked sultan
With noble and pleasing words.

app.lem: Þan seyd þe quen to hem þan
app.rdg: Then the queen said to them:
“How is your lord the sultan,

app.lem: Þat is so noble a kniȝt?’
app.rdg: Who is so noble a knight?”
The messengers did answer:

app.lem: ‘He farþ as wele as ani man,
app.rdg: “He is as well as any man,
And is your friend, indeed.”

app.lem: Þe quen seyd, wiþ milde chere,
app.rdg: The queen said, in a humble manner:
“He will be all the better because of my daughter,
By Jesus [who is] full of might.

app.lem: Mi douhter is nouȝt to him to gode;
app.rdg: My daughter is not too god for him,

app.lem: Y vouchesaue on him mi blode,
app.rdg: On my life, I promise him,

app.lem: Þei sche were ten so briȝt.’
app.rdg: Even if she were ten times as lovely.”
The messengers readied themselves immediately
With many knights and hardy horses
And brought her into a chariot.

app.lem: Þe king & þe quen were vnbliþe;
app.rdg: The king and queen were so unhappy;

app.lem: Her sorwe couþe þai noman kiþe,
app.rdg: They could express their sorrow to no man

app.lem: When þai seye hir forþ fare.
app.rdg: When they saw her going away.

app.lem: [Þai seye it miȝt non oþer go;
app.rdg: [They saw that (the chariot) might not ever return;
They gave her up to God forevermore
And kissed their daughter there].
Then they went into the bedroom.

app.lem: When þai were togider boþe to,
app.rdg: When they two were both together,
Then all of their concern was loosed.

app.lem: Þe king was in sorwe bounde,
app.rdg: The king was bound by his sorrow;

app.lem: Þe quen swoned mani a stounde,
app.rdg: The queen fainted many times
For their beloved daughter.
The knights and ladies found them there
And kept them safe and sound,
And comforted them with their company.
Thus the queen and the king
Lived in sorrow and concern, mourning;

app.lem: Gret diol it was to here.
app.rdg: Such a pity it was to hear!

app.lem: Her care was euer aliche newe;
app.rdg: Their concern was always renewed;
It changed their color and their appearance
Because of sorrow and guilty countenance.

app.lem: Nov late we ben alle her morning,
app.rdg: Not, let us leave behind all of their mourning,

app.lem: & telle we of þat maiden ȝing
app.rdg: And let us tell of that young maiden

app.lem: Þat to þe soudan is fare.
app.rdg: Who has gone to the sultan.

app.lem: He com wiþ mani gret lording
app.rdg: He came with many mighty lords

app.lem: For to welcome þat swete þing
app.rdg: To welcome that precious woman

app.lem: When sche was brouȝt in chare.
app.rdg: When she was brought in her chariot.

app.lem: He kist hir wel mani a siþe;
app.rdg: He kissed her many times;

app.lem: His ioie couþe he noman kiþe,
app.rdg: He could express his joy to no man.
All his manners were forgotten.
She was led into her bedroom,
And she was ornately robed
Like pagan women are [veiled].

app.lem: Whan sche was cladde in riche palle,
app.rdg: When she was dressed in royal garments,

app.lem: Þe soudan dede his kniȝtes calle,
app.rdg: The sultan did summon his knights
And ordered them to retrieve the maiden.

app.lem: & when sche com into þe halle
app.rdg: When she came into the hall
Before all of the high lords,

app.lem: Toforn þe soudan þai hir sett.
app.rdg: They seated her before the sultan.

app.lem: Gret diol it was for to se
app.rdg: Such a pity it was to see

app.lem: Þe bird þat was so briȝt on ble
app.rdg: The lady who was so beautiful of complexion

app.lem: To haue so foule a mett.
app.rdg: To have so hideous a husband!

app.lem: Þei þat sche made gret solas,
app.rdg: Although she seemed to be at ease,

app.lem: Þe sorwe þat at hir hert was
app.rdg: No man could take away (396)
The sorrow that was on her heart. (395)

app.lem: & whan it was comen to niȝt
app.rdg: When nighttime had fallen,

app.lem: Þe leuedi, þat was so feir & briȝt,
app.rdg: The lady who was so fair and lovely
Did retire herself to her bedroom.
Indeed within, I tell you truly,

app.lem: A riche bed þer was ydiȝt
app.rdg: There a lavish bed was spread
For that pleasant lady.

app.lem: Þe leuedi was to bed ybrouȝt;
app.rdg: The lady was brought to bed;

app.lem: Þe soudan wild com þerin nouȝt,
app.rdg: The sultan would not enter into there
Because he would draw near the maiden for nothing, (406)

app.lem: For noþing wold he neyȝe þat may
app.rdg: Neither as an enemy nor as a companion, (405)

app.lem: Til Þat sche leued opon his lay,
app.rdg: Until she believed in his faith,
She who was of the Christian people.

app.lem: Wel loþe war a Cristen man
app.rdg: A Christian man would be loathe
To marry a pagan woman
That believed in false idols;
So too was the sultan loathe
To marry a Christian woman,

app.lem: As y finde in mi sawe.
app.rdg: As I find in my story.

app.lem: Þe soudan ȝede to bed al prest,
app.rdg: The sultan went right away to bed;
Knights and ladies lay to rest,
The people did excuse themselves.
The admirable maiden hardly slept,

app.lem: Bot al niȝt wel sore sche wepe
app.rdg: Bot al niȝt wel sore sche wepe
Until the dawn of day did rise.

app.lem: & als sche fel on slepe þore
app.rdg: There as she fell to sleep

app.lem: Her þouȝt þer stode hir bifore
app.rdg: She dreamed there stood before her
A hundred black hounds,
And they bayed at her unceasingly.

app.lem: & on þer was þat greued hir sore,
app.rdg: There was one which deeply troubled her,
Which would snatch her away;

app.lem: & sche no durst him nouȝt smite
app.rdg: She dared not to strike him

app.lem: For drede þat he wald hir bite,
app.rdg: Out of fear that he would bite her,

app.lem: Swiche maistri he gan to make.
app.rdg: So savagely did he act.

app.lem: & as sche wald fram hem fle,
app.rdg: As she would flee from them,

app.lem: Sche seye þer stond deuelen þre,
app.rdg: She saw that three devils stood there,
And each smouldered like a dragon.

app.lem: So loþliche þai were al ywrouȝt
app.rdg: They were all so hideously formed,

app.lem: & ich in hond a gleiue brouȝt,
app.rdg: And each wielded a glaive in its hand,
[So] she was sorely afraid.

app.lem: On Ihesu Crist was alle hir þouȝt,
app.rdg: All of her hope was on Jesus Christ;

app.lem: Þerfore þe fendes derd hir nouȝt,
app.rdg: Therefore the fiends did not offend her,
Not in any way.

app.lem: Fro þe fendes sche passed sounde,
app.rdg: She escaped safely from the fiends,
And there a hound ran up behind her
With wide, grey brows.

app.lem: Almost he hadde hir drawen adoun,
app.rdg: He had almost dragged her down,
But through the passion of Jesus Christ
She was saved from there.
Y et she believed, without deceit,

app.lem: Als sche lay in hir sweuening,
app.rdg: As she lay tossing and turning,
Which is terrible to tell,

app.lem: Þat blac hounde hir was folweing
app.rdg: The black hound was following her.
Then a knight in white clothing (451)
Spoke to her in his valor (450)

app.lem: In white cloþes, als a kniȝt,
app.rdg: Through the might of Jesus, heaven’s king, (449)
And said to her: “My precious lady,
There is nothing for you to be afraid of,
[Neither] of Ternagaunt [deity ascribed to Islam] nor of Muhammad.
Your Lord who suffered crucifixion

app.lem: Schal help þe at þi nede.’
app.rdg: Shall help you in your peril.”
When the maiden awoke [from her dream],

app.lem: For drede of þat wel sore sche quaked
app.rdg: She trembled violently out of fear
And dread of her nightmare.

app.lem: On hir bed sche sat al naked,
app.rdg: She sat disrobed on her bed,

app.lem: To Ihesu hir preier sche maked,
app.rdg: And she said her prayers to Jesus Christ,
Almighty heaven’s king.

app.lem: As wis as he hir dere bouȝt
app.rdg: As surely as He had dearly redeemed her,

app.lem: Of þat sweuening, in slepe sche þouȝt,
app.rdg: [She believed] the nightmare that she dreamed in her sleep
Should close upon a happy ending.
When the maiden had risen [from her bed],
The wealthy sultan of Damascus

app.lem: To his temple he gan hir bring.
app.rdg: Did bring her to his temple.

app.lem: Þan seyd þe soudan to þat may,
app.rdg: Then the sultan said to the maiden:
“You must believe in my faith
And now kneel down here,
And renounce your false beliefs

app.lem: Þat þou hast leued on mani a day,
app.rdg: Which you have believed in for so long,
And worship Saint [Prophet] Muhammad.
Surely, unless you will do this soon,

app.lem: Þi fader y schal wiþ wer slon.
app.rdg: You father shall be slain in battle.
By Jove and Pluto,
And by Muhammad and Ternagaunt,

app.lem: Þer schal noman ben his waraunt,
app.rdg: No man shall be his protector,
[Neither any] emperor, nor crowned king.”

app.lem: Þe maiden answerd wiþ mild chere
app.rdg: In a humble manner, the maiden answered

app.lem: To þe soudan, as ȝe may here,
app.rdg: To the sultan, as you may hear:
“Sire, I will do nothing to offend you.

app.lem: Teche me now & lat me here
app.rdg: Teach me now, and let me hear

app.lem: Hou y schal make mi preiere
app.rdg: How I should say my prayer
When I believe in them.
I will devote myself to Muhammad
And give up my Lord Jesus Christ
Who made Adam and Eve.
Thereafter will I serve you in all things,
[Whether] early or late, loud or soft,
In the morning and at dusk.”

app.lem: Þan was þe soudan glad & bliþe,
app.rdg: Then the sultan was glad and happy,
And thanked Muhammad over and over
Since she was converted;

app.lem: His ioie couþe he noman kiþe.
app.rdg: To nobody could he express his joy

app.lem: He bad hir gon & kis swiþe
app.rdg: He ordered her to go and kiss at once
“All of your gods, one after the other.”
She kissed Muhammad and Apollyon,
Ishtar, and Lord Jove
Out of fear of his terrible threats.

app.lem: & while sche was in þe temple [þer]
app.rdg: While she stayed [there] in the temple
Of Ternagaunt and Jupiter,
She learned the heathen faith.

app.lem: & þei sche al þe lawes couþe,
app.rdg: Although she understood all of the tenets

app.lem: & seyd hem openliche wiþ hir mouþe,
app.rdg: And professed them outwardly with her mouth,
She had not forgotten Jesus.

app.lem: Wher þat sche was, bi norþe or souþe,
app.rdg: Wherever she was, be it north or south [no matter the location],

app.lem: No minstral wiþ harp no crouþe
app.rdg: No performer playing the harp or lyre
Could ever change her conviction.
Night and day, the sultan was convinced

app.lem: Þat sche hadde leued opon his lay,
app.rdg: That she had believed in his faith,
But he was none the wiser,

app.lem: For when sche was bi hirselue on
app.rdg: Because when she was alone by herself,

app.lem: To Ihesu sche made hir mon,
app.rdg: She said her prayer to Jesus

app.lem: Þat alle þis world haþ wrouȝt.
app.rdg: Who has created the entire world.

app.lem: Þe soudan dede cri þat tide
app.rdg: At that time, the sultan did announce
To every corner of his kingdom
To hold a tournament;

app.lem: & duhti men on hors to ride,
app.rdg: The mighty men [rode] out on their horses,
And he enfeoffed them at that time,
And did make them knights.
The trumpets sounded forth;
Knights spurred out of line
On white and black horses.

app.lem: Þer miȝt men se sone & swiþe
app.rdg: Men could watch then and there
Strong men show off their strength
For the maiden’s sake.
The Christian maiden and the sultan
Remained within the castle
To view the tournament.
When the tournament had begun,

app.lem: Þer was samned mani a man
app.rdg: There were gathered many men
Of Muslims strong and bold.

app.lem: To sen þer was a semly siȝt,
app.rdg: To watch there was a wonderful sight

app.lem: Of þritti þousend of helmes briȝt,
app.rdg: Of thirty-thousand shining helmets,

app.lem: In gest as it is told.
app.rdg: As it is told in the legend.

app.lem: Þai leyden on as þai were wroþe
app.rdg: They struggled as if they were mad
With both swords and with maces,
Knights both young and old.

app.lem: Wel mani helme þer was ofweued,
app.rdg: So many helmets were struck off,
Many visors [were] split in half,
And knights [were] driven to the ground.

app.lem: Sum þer fel doun on her heued,
app.rdg: There some fell down on their heads,

app.lem: & sum in þe diche lay todreued,
app.rdg: And some lay fallen in the ditch,
And cried out, badly wounded.

app.lem: Þe turnament last þo, y pliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed, the tournament lasted this long,

app.lem: Fram þe morwe to þe niȝt,
app.rdg: From dawn to dusk,
Of men of abounding power.

app.lem: Amorwe þe soudan wedded þat may
app.rdg: The next morning, the sultan married the maiden

app.lem: In þe maner of his lay,
app.rdg: In keeping the customs of his faith,

app.lem: In gest as it is founde.
app.rdg: As it is found in the legend.

app.lem: Atte his bridale was noble fest,
app.rdg: At the reception was a noble feast,
Sumptuous, fit for a king, and formal;
[There were] dukes [and] crowned kings.

app.lem: For þer was melodi wiþ þe mest
app.rdg: There was the finest song
Of harps and fiddles, and legends sung
Of celebrated heroes.

app.lem: Þer was ȝeuen to þe menstrels
app.rdg: There were given to the performers
Royal robes and many precious gems
[Befitting] of earls and barons.
The feast lasted fourteen days,
With enough of meat and drink, indeed,
Plentiful and great in store.

app.lem: Þat leuedi, so feir & so fre,
app.rdg: The lady so lovely and so noble

app.lem: Was wiþ hir lord bot moneþes þre
app.rdg: Was with her husband for but three months

app.lem: Þan he gat hir wiþ childe.
app.rdg: Before he had made her pregnant.

app.lem: When it was geten sche chaunged ble;
app.rdg: When she became pregnant, she changed in appearance.

app.lem: Þe soudan himself þat gan se,
app.rdg: The sultan himself did see it;
He was joyous and exciteful.

app.lem: Þerwhile sche was wiþ child, apliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed, while she was pregnant,

app.lem: Sche bad to Ihesu ful of miȝt
app.rdg: She begged of Jesus, full of might,

app.lem: Fram schame he schuld hir schilde.
app.rdg: [That] he should defend her from shame.
At the end of forty weeks

app.lem: Þe leuedi was deliuerd o[f] bende
app.rdg: The lady was brought out of labor
Through the help of mild Mary.
When the child was born,
The women were appalled thereby

app.lem: For lim no hadde it non.
app.rdg: Because [the baby] had no limbs.

app.lem: Bot as a rond of flesche yschore
app.rdg: But like a lump of butchered flesh

app.lem: In chaumber it lay hem bifore
app.rdg: It lay before them in the bedroom,
Lacking blood and bones.

app.lem: For sorwe þe leuedi wald dye
app.rdg: The lady wished to die of grief

app.lem: For it hadde noiþer nose no eye,
app.rdg: Because it had not either a nose or eyes,

app.lem: Bot lay ded as þe ston.
app.rdg: But lay as dead as a stone.

app.lem: Þe soudan com to chaumber þat tide,
app.rdg: The sultan entered the bedroom at that moment

app.lem: & wiþ his wiif he gan to chide
app.rdg: And began to blame his wife
For the trouble that had come of her:
“Oh dame,” he said before her,
“You are cursed by my gods,
I prove with sound judgement:

app.lem: Þe childe þat is here of þe born
app.rdg: The child which is born of you here

app.lem: Boþe lim & liþ it is forlorn
app.rdg: Is deprived of both life and limb
All because of your false belief.
You do not believe truly
On Jupiter or on Apollyon,
[And pray] neither in the morning nor in the evening,

app.lem: No in Mahoun no in Teruagant,
app.rdg: Not on Muhammad nor on Ternagaunt.

app.lem: Þerfore is lorn þis litel faunt,
app.rdg: That is why this little child is hopeless,
No wonder the gods disturb me!”
Then the lady answered and said,

app.lem: Þer sche lay in care & wo,
app.rdg: There where she lay in concern and woe:
“Dear sire, let be that thought;

app.lem: Þe child was ȝeten bitven ous to;
app.rdg: The child was gotten between us both.

app.lem: For þi bileue it farþ so
app.rdg: Because you believe this so happens

app.lem: Bi him þat ous haþ wrouȝt.
app.rdg: By He who has created us,

app.lem: Take now þis flesche, & bere it anon
app.rdg: Take this flesh, and bring it at once
Before every one of your gods,

app.lem: Þat þou no lete it nouȝt.
app.rdg: So that you spare it nothing.
Pray to all of your gods together,
As you are loved and dear to them,

app.lem: To liue þat it be brouȝt.
app.rdg: That it be brought to life.
“If Muhammad and Jove can

app.lem: Make it fourmed after a man
app.rdg: Have it fashioned like a man
With life and healthy limbs,

app.lem: Bi Ihesu Crist, þat þis warld wan,
app.rdg: By Jesus Christ who has redeemed this world,

app.lem: Y schal leue þe better þan
app.rdg: I shall love you better than

app.lem: Þat þai ar ful of miȝt.
app.rdg: They do, who are full of might.

app.lem: & bot þai it to liue bring
app.rdg: Unless they bring it to life,

app.lem: Y nil leuen on hem noþing
app.rdg: For nothing will I rely on them,
Neither by day nor by night.”

app.lem: Þe soudan toke þat flesche anon;
app.rdg: The sultan took the flesh at once;

app.lem: Into his temple he gan to gon
app.rdg: He did enter into his temple
Where his gods were installed.

app.lem: Biforn his goddes he gan it leyn,
app.rdg: He offered it up before his gods,
And held up both of his hands

app.lem: While men miȝt go fiue mile.
app.rdg: For as much time as a man could walk five miles.

app.lem: ‘A miȝtful Mahoun’ he gan to seyn,
app.rdg: “Ah, mighty Muhammad,” he began to say,
“And Ternagaunt of so much power,

app.lem: In ȝou was neuer no gile.
app.rdg: There was never deceit among you.
Saint Jupiter and Apollyon,
Ishtar and Lord Jove,
Help me now in this peril.”

app.lem: Oft he kneled & oft he ros,
app.rdg: Often he kneeled and often he stood,

app.lem: & crid so long til he was hos;
app.rdg: And shouted so long that he lost his voice,
[But] all of his effort he wasted.
When he had finished praying

app.lem: & alle þat euer he couþe he seyd,
app.rdg: All that he had ever learned to say,

app.lem: Þe flesche lay stille as ston.
app.rdg: The flesh lay as still as a stone.

app.lem: Anon he stirt vp at a breyd,
app.rdg: Suddenly, he stood upright,

app.lem: & in his hert he was atreyd
app.rdg: And in his heart he was torn

app.lem: For lim no hadde it non.
app.rdg: Because it [still] had no limbs.

app.lem: He biheld on his godes alle
app.rdg: He looked on each of his gods

app.lem: & seye þer miȝt no bot bifalle;
app.rdg: And saw that there was no help to come;
He became despondent.

app.lem: ‘O sir Mahoun’ he gan to grede,
app.rdg: “Oh sire Muhammad,” he began to groan,

app.lem: ‘Wil ȝe nouȝt helpe me at þis nede?
app.rdg: “Will you not help me in this peril?
Let the devil burn each one of you!”

app.lem: He hent a staf wiþ grete hete,
app.rdg: With profound hatred he raised a staff

app.lem: & stirt anon his godes to bete,
app.rdg: And started at once to beat his gods,
And drove them all down.

app.lem: & leyd on til he gan to swete,
app.rdg: He lashed until he began to sweat,
And gave them beatings hard and heavy
Both Jove and Pluto.
Even harder did he pummel
Jupiter and Apollyon,
And broke their arms and crowns.
On Ternagaunt which was their brother,

app.lem: He no lete neuer a lime wiþ oþer,
app.rdg: He left not a limb with its opposite,
Neither on his god Muhammad.

app.lem: & when he hadde beten hem gode won,
app.rdg: When he had thoroughly beaten each one of them,

app.lem: ȝete lay þe flesche stille so ston
app.rdg: The flesh lay still as a stone
And high upon his altar.

app.lem: He tok it in his hond anon,
app.rdg: He took it in his hands at once;
He entered into the bedroom,
And said: “Here, take it from me.

app.lem: Ich haue don al þat y can
app.rdg: I have done all that I can do

app.lem: To make it fourmed after a man
app.rdg: To make it fashioned like a man
By kneeling and praying.

app.lem: & for alle þat ichaue hem bisouȝt
app.rdg: For all that I have propitiated them,

app.lem: Mine godes no may help me nouȝt,
app.rdg: My gods cannot help me at all.
Let the devil set them aflame!”
Then the good woman answered
Graciously to the sultan:
“Beloved sire, hear me speak.

app.lem: Þe best rede þat y can,
app.rdg: [It is] the best advice that I know,

app.lem: Bi Ihesu Crist, þat made man,
app.rdg: By Jesus Christ who made man.
Now I will teach you myself.

app.lem: Now þou hast proued god þine
app.rdg: Now that you have tested your gods,

app.lem: ȝif me leue to asay mine,
app.rdg: Give me permission to challenge mine,
[To learn] which one is the better cure.
And, beloved sire, [I] ask this of you:

app.lem: Leue on hem þat stronger is,
app.rdg: Believe on Him that is the stronger,
For fear of further trouble.”
There the sultan answered her -

app.lem: In hert he was agreued sore
app.rdg: He was deeply grieved within his heart
To see that terrible sight -

app.lem: ‘Now, dame, ichil do bi þi lore,
app.rdg: “Now lady, I myself will act according to your judgement,

app.lem: ȝif þat y may se bifore
app.rdg: [So] that I may see before [my very eyes]

app.lem: Þi God is of swiche miȝt,
app.rdg: [If] your God is of such might

app.lem: Wiþ ani vertu þat he can,
app.rdg: That with any power that he wields,

app.lem: Make it fourmed after a man
app.rdg: [He can] make it fashioned like a man
With life and healthy limbs.
I myself will denounce each of my gods

app.lem: & to Ihesu, þi Lord, me take,
app.rdg: And give myself to your Lord Jesus,
[On my oath] as I am an honorable knight.”

app.lem: Wel bliþe was þe leuedi þan
app.rdg: Then the lady was elated

app.lem: For þat hir lord, þe riche soudan,
app.rdg: Because her husband the wealthy sultan
Had granted to her her request.

app.lem: For hope he schuld be Cristen man
app.rdg: Hoping that he should become a Christian man,

app.lem: Sche þonked him þat þis world wan,
app.rdg: She thanked Him who has redeemed this world,
And Mary His exalted mother.

app.lem: Now ginneþ here a miri pas,
app.rdg: Now here begins the delightful story
[Of] how that child was christened
With whole and healthy limbs,
And how the sultan of Damascus

app.lem: Was cristned for þat ich cas,
app.rdg: Was christened for that same reason.
Now listen and you may hear.

app.lem: Þan seyd þe leuedi in þat stounde,
app.rdg: Then the lady said in that instance:
“You have shut up in your prison
Many a Christian man.

app.lem: Do seche oueralle bi loft & grounde,
app.rdg: Do search it thoroughly, from top to bottom,

app.lem: ȝif ani Cristen prest be founde
app.rdg: And if any Christian priest is found,
Bring him before me then.

app.lem: & y schal, ar tomorwe at none
app.rdg: Before tomorrow noon, I shall

app.lem: Wite what Ihesu Crist can done
app.rdg: Demonstrate what Jesus Christ can do
Better than your false gods can.”
At once the prisons were searched;

app.lem: Þai founden a prest & forþ him brouȝt
app.rdg: They found a priest, and brought him forward
By the order of the sultan.

app.lem: He com bifor þat leuedi fre,
app.rdg: He came before that noble lady

app.lem: & gret hir feir opon his kne,
app.rdg: And greeted her falling down on his knee,
And said with deep sighing:
“Madame, may you be blessed
By Jesus Christ in trinity,
Who was born of Mary.”
The lady said, “Are you a priest?

app.lem: Tel me soþe ȝif þat tow best.
app.rdg: Tell me truly, if that is what you are.
Are you learned in Christrian doctrine?”
“Madame,” said the priest at once,
“I was [ordained a priest] in the word of God
Twenty winters ago or more.

app.lem: Ac Dame’ he seyd ‘bi seyn Ion,
app.rdg: “But dame,” he said, “by Saint John,

app.lem: Ten winter song y masse non,
app.rdg: I have sung no masses for ten winters,
And I have been at pains for it.

app.lem: For so long it is now gon
app.rdg: For it has gone on for so long now

app.lem: Ichaue ben in prisoun of ston
app.rdg: I have been in this prison of stone,
[That I have become] greatly unskilled and wrong.”

app.lem: Þe leuedi seyd ‘Lat be þi fare.
app.rdg: The lady said, “Let that be gone from you.

app.lem: Þou schalt be brouȝt out of þi care,
app.rdg: You shall be brought out of your concern
If you will keep yourself silent.

app.lem: For þurth þine help in þis stounde[s],
app.rdg: Through your help in this instance,

app.lem: We schul make Cristen men of houndes.
app.rdg: We shall make Chrsitian men of [pagan] hounds.

app.lem: God graunt it, ȝif it be his wille.’
app.rdg: God allow it, if it is His will.”
Then the sultan’s wife said:
“You must act quietly, without [causing] trouble,
And in the utmost secrecy.
[There is a child terrible in description.

app.lem: It haþ noiþer lim, no liif,
app.rdg: It has neither life, nor limbs,
Nor eyes with which to see.]
You must blend holy water,
And take this very flesh,

app.lem: Al for þe loue of me.
app.rdg: All for my own sake.
Christen it against sin

app.lem: In þe worþschipe of þe Faders name,
app.rdg: In worship of the Father’s name,
Who sits in trinity.

app.lem: For in him is mine hope, apliȝt;
app.rdg: “Indeed, my hope is in Him;

app.lem: Þe Fader, þat is ful of miȝt,
app.rdg: The Father, who is full of might,
Shall rid me of my sorrow.
If it were properly christened,

app.lem: It schuld haue fourme to se bi siȝt
app.rdg: It should have the features to see by sight
[And] to move with life and limb.”
The lady ordered at once

app.lem: Hir maidens out of chaumber gon
app.rdg: Her maidens to go out of the bedroom,
Out of fear of treason.

app.lem: Þe prest no leng nold abide;
app.rdg: The priest would wait no longer;

app.lem: A feir vessel he tok þat tide,
app.rdg: He chose a lovely vessel at that moment
And began to blend holy water.

app.lem: At missomer tide þat ded was don
app.rdg: On midsummer’s day, the deed was done

app.lem: Þurth help of God þat sitt in trone,
app.rdg: Through the help of God who sits enthroned,
As I may tell you.

app.lem: Þe prest toke þe flesche anon,
app.rdg: The priest took up the flesh at once

app.lem: & cleped it þe name of Ion
app.rdg: And called it by the name of John
In observance of the day,
And just as it was christened,
It had life and limbs and a face,
And cried with great fervor.
It had hair and flesh and skin,
And [to him] all of this occurred,

app.lem: In gest as y ȝou say.
app.rdg: In the legend as I tell you.

app.lem: Feirer child miȝt non be bore;
app.rdg: A more lovely child might never be born.

app.lem: It no hadde neuer a lime forlore;
app.rdg: Altogether, it was so well shaped (783)
[As if] it had never lacked a limb before. (782).

app.lem: Þe prest no lenge duelled þore,
app.rdg: The priest lingered there no longer,
But stepped out to tell the sultan

app.lem: Þer he was in þe halle.
app.rdg: Where he was in the hall.

app.lem: Þat leuedi, þer sche lay in bed,
app.rdg: Where the lady lay in her bed
That was ornately spread
With gold and purple cloths,

app.lem: Þe child sche toke to hir bliue,
app.rdg: She held the child quickly to herself,
And thanked our Lady [Mary] with five exhortations

app.lem: Þe feir grace þer was bifalle.
app.rdg: For the fair grace which had happened there.
She said: “Lord I pray you,
Almighty God in trinity,
To give me the strength and patience

app.lem: Þat y may þat day yse
app.rdg: That I might see the day
My husband would be christened,
The sultan of Damascus.”

app.lem: Þan cam þe soudan, þat was blac;
app.rdg: Then came the sultan, who[se skin] was black;

app.lem: Sche schewed him þe child & spac,She showed him the child, and [it babbled],
app.rdg: She showed him the child, and [it babbled],
With life and limbs and face.
She said, “[Neither] Muhammad nor Apollyon

app.lem: Is nouȝt worþ be brostle of a swin
app.rdg: Is worth even the bristle of a pig
Against the grace of my Lord.”
The sultan said: “My beloved,
Indeed I am wholly glad

app.lem: Of þis child þat y se.’
app.rdg: By this child that I see.”
“Yes sire, by Saint Martin,
If the half of him were yours
You might be rightly glad.”
“Oh dame,” he said, “What do you mean?

app.lem: Is it nouȝt min þat y biȝat?’
app.rdg: Is it not mine that I have begotten?”
Then she said, “No sire,

app.lem: ‘Bot þou were cristned so it is
app.rdg: Unless you are christened like [the child] is,

app.lem: Þou no hast no part þeron, ywis,
app.rdg: You have not a part in him, indeed,

app.lem: Noiþer of þe child ne of me.
app.rdg: Neither of the child nor of me.
“Unless you will renounce Muhammad,

app.lem: & to Ihesu, mi Lord, þe take,
app.rdg: And give yourself to my Lord Jesus
Who suffered five wounds

app.lem: [&] anon þou do þe Cristen make,
app.rdg: [And] you make yourself a Christian at once,

app.lem: Þou miȝt be ferd for sorwe & wrake
app.rdg: You might be in fear of grief and pain
So long as you are alive.

app.lem: & ȝif þou were a Cristen man
app.rdg: But if you were a Christian man,

app.lem: Boþe were þine’ sche seyd þan,
app.rdg: Both [of us] would be yours,” she said then,
“The child as well as your wife.

app.lem: When þou art dede þou schalt wende
app.rdg: When you have died, your soul shall leave
Into unending happiness;
Then no man may comprehend your joy.”

app.lem: þe soudan seye wele bi siȝt
app.rdg: The sultan saw clearly with his own eyes

app.lem: Þat Ihesu was of more miȝt
app.rdg: That Jesus was of greater might
Than was his false belief.
He said, “Dame, right away
I myself will renounce my [gods], indeed;
They shall be burnt and scattered.

app.lem: Ac telle me now, par charite,
app.rdg: But for the love of God, tell me now,

app.lem: & for þe loue þou has[t] to me,
app.rdg: And for the love you have [given] to me,

app.lem: What schal y seyn in sawe?
app.rdg: What shall I say with my words?
Now that I have recanted my religion,

app.lem: Tel me now what is ȝour fay,
app.rdg: Tell me now what is your faith,
And I will gladly learn it.”

app.lem: Þan seyd þat leuedi, hende & fre,
app.rdg: Then that kind and noble lady said:
“Understand sire, for the love of God,
The nature of Jesus Christ.

app.lem: Hou he was & euer schal be
app.rdg: How he was and ever shall be
One God in three persons,
Reincarnated in the virgin Mary,

app.lem: & in hir bodi nam flesche & bl[o]d,
app.rdg: And in her body took on flesh and blood;

app.lem: & hou he bouȝt ous on þe rode
app.rdg: And how he redeemed us on the cross
On the Good Friday,

app.lem: & hou his gost went to helle
app.rdg: And how his spirit descended into hell
To overthrow Satan’s dominion,
And ransomed humankind.

app.lem: Þe þridde day, in þe morning,
app.rdg: “[On] the morning of the third day,

app.lem: To liue he ros, wiþouten lesing,
app.rdg: He rose to life, without deceit,

app.lem: As he com of þe rode,
app.rdg: After he came off the cross;
And [He] gave comfort to his friends,

app.lem: & steye to heuen as miȝtful king
app.rdg: And ascended into heaven as a mighty king
In both His flesh and blood.

app.lem: As it is founden in holy writ
app.rdg: According to the Holy Scriptures,

app.lem: On his Fader riȝt hond he sitt,
app.rdg: He sits at the right hand of His Father,
And is mild in manner.

app.lem: As it is writen in þe crede
app.rdg: As it is written in [the Apostle’s] Creed,

app.lem: He demeþ boþe þe quic & ded,
app.rdg: He judges the living and the dead,
The sick as well as the strong.
“He shall scatter all this world,

app.lem: & man arise fram ded to liue
app.rdg: And men will rise from death to life
To receive the proper judgement [of their sins].
Then shall Jesus, without strife,
Reveal His five bloody wounds

app.lem: Þat he for ous gan fond.
app.rdg: Which he did suffer for us.
Then He shall, without mistake,

app.lem: Deme ich man after he is,
app.rdg: Judge each man according to his character,
[Whether] earl, or baron, or serf.
Believe on this,” she said then,

app.lem: ‘& do þe make a Cristen man,
app.rdg: “And do make yourself a Christian man.
For nothing should you wait.”

app.lem: Þan seyd þe soudan ‘dame, be stille.
app.rdg: Then the sultan said: “Dame, be at peace.

app.lem: Y schal be cristned þurth Godes wille
app.rdg: I shall be christened according to God’s will
Before the third day [from now].

app.lem: Loþ me were mi soule to spille;
app.rdg: I would be loathe to waste my soul;

app.lem: Preye now þe prest he com ous tille
app.rdg: Ask the priest to present himself to us
And teach me the Christian faith

app.lem: As priueliche as it may be,
app.rdg: As secretly as it may be [done],

app.lem: Þat noman wite bot we þre,
app.rdg: So that nobody knows except us three
To the best that you can.

app.lem: & ani it wist, heye or lowe,
app.rdg: If anyone finds out, noble or peasant,

app.lem: Þou schalt be brent & y todrawe,
app.rdg: You shall be burnt and I hanged
If we recant our faith.”
Then at once the priest answered [the summons]
Obediently to the sultan:
“Sire, I am here prepared

app.lem: Wiþ alle þe pouwer þat y can
app.rdg: With all the power that I have
To make you a Christian man,
And to learn the law of God.”

app.lem: His hond opon his brest he leyd;
app.rdg: He laid his hand upon his breast;
“In the word of God,” he swore and said,
“To the both of you together,

app.lem: Wel trewe & trusti schal y be
app.rdg: Honest and faithful shall I be

app.lem: Wiþ alle þat euer falleþ to me
app.rdg: In all that was ever entrusted to me
To help by my authority.”

app.lem: Amorwe when þe prest gan wake,
app.rdg: In the morning, when the priest awoke,

app.lem: A wel feir fessel he gan take
app.rdg: He did take a lovely vessel
[And filled it] with crisp, clear water;

app.lem: & halwed it for þe soudan sake,
app.rdg: He consecrated it for the sultan’s sake
And began to make his prayers
To Jesus, whom Judas sold,
And to Mary His beloved mother,

app.lem: Þo þat þe soudan cristned were,
app.rdg: So that when the sultan would be christened,
Who was so strong and bold,

app.lem: He schuld ȝif him miȝt & space
app.rdg: He should give [the sultan] strength and patience
To justly rule his kingdom (912)
By his virtue and his grace. (911)

app.lem: & when it was liȝt of day
app.rdg: When it was the light of day,

app.lem: Þe riche soudan, þer he lay,
app.rdg: The wealthy sultan, from where he slept,
Began to stir awake.

app.lem: To þe prest he went his way,
app.rdg: He made his way to the priest

app.lem: & halp him alle þat he may
app.rdg: To help him in all that he could
That came under his responsibility.
Then when the priest had
Made ready everything for which he was responsible
In every which way,

app.lem: Þe soudan, wiþ gode wille anon,
app.rdg: The sultan, by his own will at once
Put off every thread of his clothing
To receive his baptism.
The Christian priest was named Cleophas;

app.lem: He cleped þe soudan of Damas
app.rdg: He christened the sultan of Damascus
After his own name.

app.lem: His hide, þat blac & loþely was,
app.rdg: His skin, which was black and ugly,

app.lem: Al white bicom, þurth Godes gras,
app.rdg: Became completely white by the grace of God,
Clear and without blemish.

app.lem: & when þe soudan seye þat siȝt
app.rdg: When the sultan saw that sight,

app.lem: Þan leued he wele on God almiȝt;
app.rdg: Then he believed fully on the Almighty God;
His sorrow turned to joy.

app.lem: & when þe prest hadde alle yseyd,
app.rdg: When the priest had said everything
And anointed him with holy water,
They went together to the bedroom.

app.lem: When he com þer þe leuedi lay,
app.rdg: When he came to where the lady lay,
“Look, dame,” he began to say,
“Certainly, your God is true.”

app.lem: Þe leuedi þonked God þat day,
app.rdg: The lady praised God that day.

app.lem: For ioie sche wepe wiþ eyȝen gray;
app.rdg: For joy, she wept with her grey eyes;
Unmistakably she recognized her husband.

app.lem: Þan wist sche wele in hir þouȝt
app.rdg: Then she knew fully in her mind

app.lem: Þat on Mahoun leued he nouȝt
app.rdg: That he believed not on Muhammad,
Because his [skin] color had changed.

app.lem: For þat hir lord was cristned so
app.rdg: Because her husband was thusly christened,

app.lem: Oway was went al hir wo,
app.rdg: Her sorrow was all forgotten

app.lem: Hir ioie gan wax al newe.
app.rdg: And her joy rose up anew.

app.lem: ‘Mi lord’ sche seyd wiþ hert fre,
app.rdg: “My husband,” she said with noble heart,
“Now send this priest in secrecy
To my father the king.

app.lem: & pray him, for þe loue of me,
app.rdg: And seek him, for the love of me,

app.lem: Þat he com swiþe hider to þe
app.rdg: That he comes here to you quickly

app.lem: Wiþ alle þat he may bring.
app.rdg: With all that he can carry.

app.lem: & when mi fader is to þe come
app.rdg: When my father has come [to meet with] you,

app.lem: Do cristen þi lond, alle & some,
app.rdg: Do convert every which one of your subjects,
Both the old and the young.

app.lem: & he þat wil be cristned nouȝt,
app.rdg: Whoever will not be christened,

app.lem: Loke to þe deþ þat he be brouȝt,
app.rdg: See that he is put to death
Without any delay.”

app.lem: Þe soudan tok þe prest bi hond,
app.rdg: The sultan took the priest by the hand,

app.lem: & bad him wende & nouȝt no wond
app.rdg: And ordered him to go and not delay

app.lem: To þe king of Tars ful ȝare;
app.rdg: To the King of Tars posthaste,
To do everything to make him understand

app.lem: Hou Ihesu Crist þurth his sond,
app.rdg: How through the Gospel of Jesus Christ

app.lem: Haþ brouȝt hem out of care.
app.rdg: They had been delivered from their sorrow.

app.lem: & bid him bring wiþ him his ost,
app.rdg: He requested [that the king] bring his armies with him,
Secretly, and without show of force,
Because he would want for nothing.
Cleophas, with good intent,
Started off for Tars (972)
To obey the sultan’s command. (971)
When the priest Sir Cleophas

app.lem: Com to þe court þurth Godes grace
app.rdg: Arrived at the court by the grace of God
Without any delay,

app.lem: He teld þe king alle þat cas
app.rdg: He told the entire story to the king:

app.lem: Hou þe child ded born was
app.rdg: How the child was delivered stillborn
As a deformed creature,

app.lem: & þurth þe preier of his wiif
app.rdg: And through the prayers of his wife

app.lem: Hou God hadde sent it leme & liif
app.rdg: How God had given it limb and life
[When immersed] in the water at its christening;
[And] how the pagan sultan
Had become a Christian man
Through the might of heaven’s king.

app.lem: He radde þe letter þat he brouȝt,
app.rdg: He read the letter which he brought;

app.lem: & in þe letter he fond ywrouȝt,
app.rdg: And in the letter he read,

app.lem: In gest as y ȝou say,
app.rdg: Just as I tell you in the legend,

app.lem: Hou þat þe soudan him bisouȝt
app.rdg: How the sultan requested him
To meet with him, and not delay,
On a specified day.

app.lem: & bring wiþ him alle his ost
app.rdg: [And he read] to bring with him all of his armies

app.lem: To take his lond bi euerich cost,
app.rdg: To take his subjects from every corner [of the kingdom],
And search throughout his country;

app.lem: Who þat wold nouȝt cristned be
app.rdg: Whoever would not be christened

app.lem: He schuld be honged opon a tre,
app.rdg: Should be hanged upon a tree,
Without any delay.
No man could have been happier.

app.lem: He cleped his barouns & þe quen,
app.rdg: He summoned his barons and the queen,
And told them this with his words
How the sultan, strong and brave,
Was christened without a doubt
And believed in the Christian faith.

app.lem: ‘& Þerfore he haþ don sent me bi sond
app.rdg: “Therefore, he has sent me by his messenger

app.lem: He wil do cristen alle his lond,
app.rdg: That he will christen each of his subjects,

app.lem: ȝif þat he mit wel fawe.
app.rdg: If any of them will eagerly accept [the baptism].

app.lem: & he þat wil nouȝt take cristening,
app.rdg: And whoever will not take the christening,

app.lem: No be he neuer so heye lording,
app.rdg: Even if he is his highest lord,
He shall be hanged and drawn.

app.lem: & þerfore y pray ȝou now riȝt,
app.rdg: “Therefore I ask you at once,
Earl, baron, duke, and knight,
Do order all of your men

app.lem: Wiþ helme on heued & brini briȝt
app.rdg: That you be made ready (1013)

app.lem: Þat ȝe ben alle redi diȝt
app.rdg: With helms on heads and bright coats of mail (1012)

app.lem: To help me at þis nede.’
app.rdg: To help me at this need.”

app.lem: Þai sent oueral, bi ich a side,
app.rdg: They sent throughout every corner [of the kingdom]

app.lem: For mani Cristen men þat tide,
app.rdg: After many Christian men at that time,
Who were courageous in action.

app.lem: Þe king him diȝt forto wende
app.rdg: The king prepared himself to go
With sixty-thousand manly knights;
That was a glorious company!
The king arrived without delay

app.lem: Þe selue day þat him was sett
app.rdg: On the very day he was scheduled
To venture to the sultan.
When they had met together,

app.lem: A miri greteing þer was gret
app.rdg: They were received with a happy welcome
With noblemen of every rank.

app.lem: Þer was rewþe for to sen
app.rdg: Sorrowful it was to see

app.lem: Hou þe leuedi fel on knen
app.rdg: How the lady fell on her knees
Before her father there.
There was joy and happiness as well

app.lem: To here hem speken of wele & wo,
app.rdg: To hear them speak of woe and weal,
As well of their adventures.

app.lem: Þe soudan dede his barouns calle,
app.rdg: The sultan did summon his barons,
And soon he called his knights at once,
And after them, [he called] all of his train.

app.lem: & when þai come into þe halle
app.rdg: When they came into the hall,
He said: “However it occurs,
You must be baptized.
I myself have renounced Muhammad
And have accepted Christianity.
Indeed, so must you,

app.lem: & hye þat wil nouȝt so anon
app.rdg: And they that will not [be baptized] at once,
[Everyone of them] should be beheaded,

app.lem: Bi him þat dyed on tre.’
app.rdg: By He who died on the cross.”
When he had spoken thusly
[To the] many Muslims strong and bold
Who were in his court,
Many said that they would [be baptized],
And many said that they would not
Be baptized in any way.
He let them become Christian men, (1051)

app.lem: Cristen men he lete hem make,
app.rdg: Those who would reject Muhammad, (1052)
And they were beloved and dear to him.

app.lem: & he þat dede nouȝt bi his rede,
app.rdg: And of those that did not take his advice,

app.lem: Anon he dede strike of his hed,
app.rdg: He struck off their heads at once,
Immediately with his sword.

app.lem: Þe soudan had in prisoun diȝt
app.rdg: The sultan had shut up in prison

app.lem: Ten þousend Cristen men, y pliȝt,
app.rdg: Ten-thousand Christian men, indeed,
Of many unknown peoples.
He did release them at once,
And to those who were strong and able
He gave them arms and mounts.

app.lem: & þo he seye þat miȝt nouȝt so
app.rdg: To those he saw that were not fit,

app.lem: He ȝaf hem mete & drink þerto,
app.rdg: He gave them food and plenty of drink
And everything that they needed.

app.lem: Þer miȝt men se wiþ þat soudan
app.rdg: There men might see with the sultan
Many happy Christian men,
In the legend just as we read it.

app.lem: When he hadde don þus þat tide,
app.rdg: When he had done thusly at that time,

app.lem: Oueral his lond, bi ich a side,
app.rdg: The rumor spread about (1071)
Among all of his subjects, by every corner [of the kingdom]. (1070)
At that time, five pagan kings
And many wicked, pagan dukes
With many people great and strong
Were searching about near and far
To make war against the sultan;
They said, for his treachery,
That by Muhammad and Ternagaunt,

app.lem: Þer schuld nouȝt ben his warant,
app.rdg: No one should be his defender,
But [he should be] hanged and drawn.

app.lem: Þo fif kinges of prout parayle
app.rdg: Those five kings of apparent valor

app.lem: Diȝt hem redi to þat batayle;
app.rdg: Prepared themselves for battle,
So bold and strong were they.

app.lem: Hou þe soudan gan hem aseyle,
app.rdg: Now listen, and you may hear (1086)
How the sultan did confront them, (1084)
And [hear] how they were named, without fail: (1085).
King Canadok, and King Lesias,
King Carmel, and King Clamadas,
And King Memarok their companion.

app.lem: Opon þe soudan wiþ wer þai went.
app.rdg: They moved with war against the sultan;

app.lem: His men þai slouȝ, his tounes brent,
app.rdg: They killed his subjects [and] they burnt his towns
With strength and awesome power.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars & þe soudan
app.rdg: The King of Tars and the sultan

app.lem: Day of bateyle þai gun tan
app.rdg: Did set a day for battle
Against those five kings.

app.lem: Ac euer oȝein a Cristen man
app.rdg: Against a single Christian man
There were more than ten pagan hounds
Of Muslims strong and sturdy.

app.lem: Now herkneþ to me boþe eld & ȝing
app.rdg: Now listen to me, both old and young,
How the sultan and the king
Did drive among them,
And how that day, the Muslims
Hopped around headless for their audacity;
Now listen and you may hear.
At that moment, the Christian sultan

app.lem: Tok a spere & gan to ride
app.rdg: Equipped a spear and began to ride
Upon Canadok, who was brave.
But Canadok, with great pride,

app.lem: Wiþ a spere gan him abide
app.rdg: Anticipated him with a spear
To counter him, and not leisurely.

app.lem: So hard þai driuen togider þere
app.rdg: There they closed at arms so strongly
That both of their lances [locked] together
[And] shattered between them.

app.lem: Þe soudan drouȝ his fauchoun gode,
app.rdg: The sultan drew his dependable falchion;

app.lem: Þe kinges heued wiþ alle þe hode
app.rdg: He struck off quick and clean (1116)

app.lem: He strok of quite and clene.
app.rdg: The king’s head, still within the hood. (1115)
King Lesias of Tiberias [a town in Judaea]

app.lem: To þe soudan he gan heye,
app.rdg: Did hasten toward the sultan
To avenge his friend Canadok;

app.lem: Wiþ a spere þat was trusti
app.rdg: With a trusty spear

app.lem: He rode to þe soudan wel an hey,
app.rdg: He rode in haste upon the sultan,
Intending to have him killed.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars bitven hem rod,
app.rdg: The King of Tars rode between them
And he suffered King Lesias’s blow,

app.lem: As y finde in mi sawe.
app.rdg: As I read in my story.

app.lem: & smot him so on þe scheld
app.rdg: But he struck [King Lesias] so hard on his shield
hat he tumbled to the ground
And had unhorsed him.

app.lem: He lepe on hors & gan to ride,
app.rdg: He vaulted on another horse and did ride

app.lem: & slouȝ adoun bi ich a side
app.rdg: And strike down on every side
Whomever he found before him.

app.lem: Wham þat Lesias hit in þat tide,
app.rdg: Whomever Lesias hit in that instance,

app.lem: Were he douk or prince o pride
app.rdg: Whether he was a duke or a valiant prince,
He dealt him a deadly wound.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars com wiþ a spere
app.rdg: The King of Tars came with a spear

app.lem: & þurth his sides he gan it bere
app.rdg: And did drive it through his side

app.lem: Þat ded he fel to grounde.
app.rdg: So that he fell dead on the ground.

app.lem: Þan sett þe Sarraȝins vp a cri,
app.rdg: Then the Muslims raised up a cry,
“Ah, Muhammad, most masterful,
Help us in this peril.”

app.lem: When king Carmel herd þat, him was wo -
app.rdg: King Carmel was stricken when he heard that -

app.lem: [To fiȝt anon he was ful þro] -
app.rdg: [He had been eager to fight at once] -

app.lem: A spere an hond he hent.
app.rdg: He hefted a spear in his hand.

app.lem: He priked his stede & dede him go;
app.rdg: He spurred his steed and made it run;

app.lem: He þouȝt þe king [of] Tars to slo
app.rdg: He intended to kill the King [of] Tars
Before he disengaged.

app.lem: He smot þe king of Tars þat tide
app.rdg: That moment, he struck the King of Tars

app.lem: Þurth his hauberk a wounde wide
app.rdg: ith a deep wound through his coat of mail

app.lem: Þat neiȝe he hadde him schent.
app.rdg: [So that he] nearly had him killed.

app.lem: Þe king out of his sadel fel,
app.rdg: The King fell out of his saddle;

app.lem: Þe blod out of his wounde gan wel,
app.rdg: The blood gushed from his wound,
So that many men bemoaned him.

app.lem: For sorwe þe soudan wald wede
app.rdg: The sultan would grow mad out of grief

app.lem: When he seiȝe his woundes blede;
app.rdg: When he saw [the King’s] wound bleed;

app.lem: He rode to him wiþ mayn.
app.rdg: He rode to him with his lieutenants.
He and the Christian company

app.lem: Brouȝt þe king of Tars his stede,
app.rdg: Brought the King of Tars his horse
And sat him up again.

app.lem: & when he was on hors brauȝt
app.rdg: When he was brought upon his horse,
Whomever that he reached,

app.lem: He clef him to þe brayn.
app.rdg: He cleaved him to the brain.

app.lem: King Carmel þo to him went
app.rdg: Then King Carmel closed with him
And dealt him such another wound

app.lem: Þat ner he hadde him sleyn.
app.rdg: That he had nearly killed him.
When the sultan had seen that,

app.lem: Al wode he wex for wreþe neye.
app.rdg: He grew utterly near mad out of anger.
He rode upon King Carmel;

app.lem: He smot him on þe helme an heiȝe
app.rdg: He stuck him high upon his helm

app.lem: Þat þurth þe breyn it fleiȝe
app.rdg: So that [his falchion] sliced through his brain

app.lem: Þat no leche miȝt him hele.
app.rdg: Such that no medic could heal him.
Then King Clamadas came riding

l.app: <lem wit="#Transcription"Wiþ a glaiue to þe soudan, Upon the sultan with a glaive,

app.rdg: And intended to deal with him.
He struck [the sultan] upon his shield

app.lem: Þat neiȝe he feld him in þe feld
app.rdg: So that he nearly tumbled to the field
To crawl among the hounds.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars in þat stounde
app.rdg: At that moment, the King of Tars

app.lem: Hadde spite of þat heþen hounde
app.rdg: Held hatred for that pagan hound
Who was so strong and bold.

app.lem: He swore bi him þat þoled wounde,
app.rdg: He swore by He who suffered wounds:
“The mongrel shall fall down on the ground
Who fights thusly in the field.”
He rode upon him at once

app.lem: & smot to him a strok of miȝt;
app.rdg: And dealt to him a mighty stroke;
He cleaved his shield in two.

app.lem: & þurth his hert þe swerd gan glide,
app.rdg: The sword pierced through his heart;

app.lem: Þe blod ran out bi ich a side,
app.rdg: The blood flowed out on both sides,
And so he killed him.

app.lem: Þan was king Memaroc in gret peyn
app.rdg: Then King Memaroc was sorely afraid,

app.lem: For his four felawes were sleyn
app.rdg: Because his four companions were slain
And driven into the field.

app.lem: He priked his stede opon þe pleyn
app.rdg: He spurred his horse across the plain
And fled away with ranks and train,

app.lem: For dred to hide his heued.
app.rdg: Out of fear to save his head.

app.lem: Þe soudan seyȝe him oway ride,
app.rdg: The sultan saw him riding away;

app.lem: He priked after him in þat tide,
app.rdg: He spurred after him at that moment,
As if he wanted for nothing else.

app.lem: & smot him so aboue þe scheld
app.rdg: He struck him above the shield so that

app.lem: Þat helme & heued in þe feld
app.rdg: The helm and the head [flew across] the field,
So forcefully was it severed.
When all of the Muslims saw

app.lem: Þat Memarok was to grounde yfalle
app.rdg: That Memarok had fallen to the ground
And never to rise again,
“Alas, Muhammad,” they began to shout,
“Why do you allow the Christian men to cut us down?
Your worship is in vain.”

app.lem: Þai fleyȝe for dred alle yfere,
app.rdg: They all fled together out of fear
And drowned themselves in a river,
So sorely were they afraid.
The battle lasted so long,

app.lem: Til it were time of euensong,
app.rdg: That it was until the time of the evening mass

app.lem: Er þai miȝt win þe prise.
app.rdg: Before they could achieve victory.

app.lem: Þe Sarraȝins flowe bi ich a side;
app.rdg: The Muslims fled on every side;

app.lem: Þe Cristen folk after gan ride,
app.rdg: The Chrisitan people did ride after them
And spilled their brains and blood.

app.lem: Þer was non þat miȝt him hide
app.rdg: There was no one who could hide himself

app.lem: Þat he nas sleyn in þat tide,
app.rdg: So that he was not slain in that instance,
Who stood against them in the fight.

app.lem: & þo þat ȝold hem to þe pes
app.rdg: To those that surrendered themselves
The sultan swore, without deceit,

app.lem: Bi him þat dyed on rode,
app.rdg: By He who died upon the cross,

app.lem: He þat nold nouȝt forsake his lay
app.rdg: He who would not renounce his faith,

app.lem: He schuld forles(s)e þat ich day,
app.rdg: He should forfeit that same day

app.lem: Þe bal vp in þe hode.
app.rdg: The ball inside his hood [the head].
There were captured thirty-thousand
Muslims both dark and black
And shut up in his prison.

app.lem: & he þat wald his lay forsake
app.rdg: They who would renounce his faith,
[The sultan] let them become Christian men
With pious devotion;

app.lem: & þai þat wald be cristned nouȝt
app.rdg: They who would not be baptized

app.lem: Into a stede þai were(e)n ybrouȝt
app.rdg: Were brought to a station
A mile outside of the town,
And Chrisitan men, without delay,

app.lem: Striken of her heuedes al bidene...
app.rdg: Struck off every one of their heads.

app.lem: Þus þe ladi wiþ hire lore
app.rdg: Thus the lady, with her wisdom,

app.lem: Brouȝte hire frendes out of sore,
app.rdg: Brought her family out of sorrow
Through the grace of Jesus Christ.

app.lem: Al þe while þat þei weore þare,
app.rdg: No man could judge the depth (1241)

app.lem: Þe joye þat was among hem ȝare,
app.rdg: Of the joy that was among them there (1240)

app.lem: No mon may telle þe space.
app.rdg: All the while that they lived. (1239)

app.lem: Whon þei weore out of world i-went
app.rdg: When they were gone out of this world
[To be] before God omnipotent,
A place was prepared for them.

app.lem: Now Jhesu, þat is ful of miht
app.rdg: Now Jesus, who is full of might,

app.lem: Graunt us alle, in heuenes liht
app.rdg: Grant us all, in Heaven’s light,

app.lem: To seo þi swete face. AMEN.
app.rdg: To see Your precious face. AMEN.
